subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?
msgSnippet: Hey, whatever it takes! :-) But really, I realise that I m a little late to this particular conversation, but it seems to me that testing even the simple
messageBody:
Hey, whatever it takes! :-)

But really, I realise that I'm a little late to this particular
conversation, but it seems to me that testing even the simple getters
and setters would fit well with the extremeness (is that a real word?)
of XP, that JUint came from.

I seem to recall that the Extreme logic, ran along the lines of:

if code reviews are good, then code review all the time by programming
in pairs.

So, would we not say that if testing is good (and I hope that we can all
agree on that one as members of a unit test framework mailing list! :-)
then should we not say let's test everything? Even the simple setters
and getters are potential sources of errors.

I realise that unit tests are not a guarantee of 100% code coverage, but
leaving out tests on even simple methods is even more guaranteed to not
give 100% code coverage.

I'd also remind us all of some of the more impressive failures in both
American and European space projects have been caused by tiny
insignificant errors. Example: A piece of 16bit oriented code being
asked to hold a value outside of it's range. Example: the U.S. team
worked in imperial while the European team worked in metric. These are
silly little mistakes, but once your VERY expensive spacerocket is
thundering into the void, you can't bring it back and debug it.

I'll be testing my getters and setters.

Just a thought. :-)

Simon

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@...
Web Developer / Programming Specialist www.landsend.com
Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526

-----Original Message-----
From: Patrick McGovern [mailto:themysterytramp@...]
Sent: Wednesday, December 26, 2001 8:47 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?


well, since "simon says" i guess i will as well :)...
"Chappell, Simon P" <simon.chappell@...> wrote:
"Trivial getter and setter methods are usually omitted."

You may feel free to omit them, but I think that I shall continue
testing them frequently! :-)

Simon

Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@...

Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526


-----Original Message-----
From: Patrick McGovern [mailto:themysterytramp@...]

Subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?


http://www.extremeprogramming.org/rules/unittests.html

second to last sentence in the first paragraph
--- Jason Rogers <jacaetev@...> wrote:
> Show me where Kent ever said "don't test the
> trivial."
>
> BTW: If you can do that, I still will test the
> trivial! Just my opinion...
>
> -jason
>
> --- Patrick McGovern <themysterytramp@...>
> wrote:
> > hey, he asked a question.
> >
> > however more seriously, I believe the XP tenets
> are
> > pretty clear on the testing of trivial methods
> like
> > this getter...we just dont bother...testing the
> > "internal state" as suggested in another email in
> this
> > thread would not be an explicit test of this
> ! getter
> > but a test of the functions that leave the object
> in
> > the tested state. It would be an implicit
> test..which
> > is cool:)
> >
> >
> > Pax Vobiscum;)
> >
> > --- "STRAYER, JON (AIT)" <jon.strayer@...>
> wrote:
> > > You need a test case for that?
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: Patrick McGovern

> > > > Sent: Friday, December 21, 2001 1:20 PM

> > > seter?
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > would the fact that it won't compile be the
> > > answer?
> > > > --- "STRAYER, JON (AIT)" <jon.strayer@...>
> > > wrote:
> > > > > What could go wrong with this getter that is
> > >! worth a
> > > > > test?
> > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > > class A {
> > > > > > private int i;
> > > > > > getI(){
> > > > > > return i;
> > > > > > }
> > > > > > }
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I want test the geter,should i make
> testcase
> > > as a
> > > > > inner class?
> > > > >
> > > >
